newsitem.title: UK: Kalamazoo sells print unit to Adare.
newsitem.headline: Kalamazoo sells print unit to Adare.

text.p: Kalamazoo Computer Group Plc said on Wednesday it was selling its Security Print Division to Ireland's Adare Printing Plc for 12 million stg in cash on completion.
Adare will pay a further 675,000 stg at the end of the year as a contribution to the division's corporation tax liability.
The Security Print Division is a specialist business forms printer, security printer and security products supplier.

Kalamazoo said the disposal, which includes a freehold property, was expected to lead to an exceptional profit of about 3.4 million stg in the year to March 31, 1998. Proceeds will be used to reduce the group's net borrowings.

"The disposal leaves Kalamazoo as a pure computer solutions business better able to pursue a strategy of focused international growth in computer related niche markets," chairman Bob Jordan said in a statement.
Kalamazoo reported pretax profits, before exceptionals of 5.93 million stg for the year to March 31, 1997, up from 5.43 million the year before.
It recommended a final dividend of 3.05 pence, making a total of 4.25 pence, up 2.4 percent. Turnover rose 19.2 percent to 77.78 million stg.
The company said it continued to incur "significant costs" from the development of its Elite product, delays to which it expects to have an adverse impact on earnings, particularly in the first half.
"However, we expect the outcome of the second half to be satisfactory," Jordan said in the results statement.
Kalamazoo, still in talks which may lead to an offer being made for the group, said the board "continues to have regard to the best interests of all shareholders".
Last month Britain's Lynx Holdings Plc withdrew from the merger talks, but Kalamazoo it was still in talks with other companies.
